title: Latest News from Science Magazine
description: Keyword search result for Alerts: News Weekly Headlines -- New results matching your keyword search query (updated daily).

items.title: A flood of Chinese graduate students in STEM was a boon to U.S. students
items.description: Study shows the influx allowed U.S. programs to expand enrollment and also benefited local businesses

items.title: Egypt joins Europe’s flagship science program, raising academic freedom concerns
items.description: Horizon Europe’s push for free inquiry clashes with Egypt’s human rights record, critics say

items.title: Exclusive: Future of chronic disease journal in limbo after cuts at CDC
items.description: Researchers dismayed by the targeting of Preventing Chronic Disease’s editorial staff

items.title: Tree rings from ancient coffins offer clues to Earth’s past
items.description: Wood from gravesites can help reconstruct historic temperatures, floods, and droughts

items.title: Chemical additive slashes carbon emissions when creating synthetic fuels
items.description: Advance in Fischer-Tropsch process could make coal-to-liquid plants cleaner

items.title: Can AI capture the mind-boggling complexity of a human cell?
items.description: Researchers are competing to make “virtual cells” that could transform biomedicine by predicting gene activity and more

items.title: New evidence? No problem. Chimps can weigh conflicting clues, just like humans
items.description: Study is first to suggest our closest relatives think about their own thoughts

items.title: How one of the world’s rarest and most valuable gemstones gets its vivid colors
items.description: Scientists finally solve mystery of ammolite’s brilliant reds, greens, and blues

items.title: Mini-tyrannosaur lived alongside T. rex, extraordinary fossil confirms
items.description: Study finds fresh evidence for Nanotyrannus, a dinosaur whose existence has long been debated

items.title: Facing claims of animal abuse, a major breeder of research dogs will close its pipeline
items.description: Ridglan Farms has agreed to stop selling beagles for scientific studies, leaving just one major U.S. supplier
